title: 114_s2392
content: The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" limits the removal of Medicare Advantage providers by MA organizations. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" restricts MA organizations from removing providers from MA plans without cause starting in 2017. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" prohibits MA organizations from removing providers from MA plans without cause, unless the provider is found to be medically negligent, in violation of legal or contractual requirements, or otherwise unfit to furnish items and services. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" prohibits MA organizations from removing providers from MA plans without cause, unless the provider is found to be medically negligent, in violation of legal or contractual requirements, or otherwise unfit to furnish items and services. Beginning with plan year 2017, an MA organization cannot consider the cost of a provider in their network as a reason to remove them mid-year. Beginning in 2017, an MA organization offering an MA plan can only remove a provider from their network for specific reasons before 60 days prior to the annual coordinated election period. Any removal must follow a fair notice and appeal process established by the Secretary. The MA organization must provide an explanation for removing a provider from their network, following a fair notice and appeal process established by the Secretary. This process applies instead of the termination or suspension of a provider contract under section 422.202(a) of title 42. Under section 422.202(a) of title 42, Code of Federal Regulations, the process for the termination or suspension of a provider contract applies to the removal of a provider from an MA plan network. Participant notice of provider removal must be given at least 60 days in advance. The MA organization must notify individuals enrolled in the plan at least 60 days before removing a provider from the network, providing names and contact information of alternative in-network providers. The MA organization must notify individuals enrolled in the plan at least 60 days before removing a provider from the network, offering information on alternative providers, continuation of treatment options, and customer service contact numbers for network changes. The MA organization must notify individuals enrolled in the plan at least 60 days before removing a provider from the network, offering information on alternative providers, continuation of treatment options, and customer service contact numbers for network changes. Additionally, the MA organization must include the notification of removal in the annual notice of change for the upcoming plan year to ensure continuity of care for individuals affected by provider removal from the network. Beginning with plan year 2017, MA organizations offering an MA plan must provide transparency in the measures used to establish or modify provider networks. This includes including specific information in the annual bid information. Providers of services or suppliers have the ability to decline participation in an MA plan network. Beginning with plan year 2017, MA organizations must provide transparency in the measures used to establish or modify provider networks. This includes specific information in the annual bid information and on the MA plan's website. Information includes measures of quality and efficiency, provider network specifications, methodology, and sample size. The Secretary requires additional information on provider network establishment or modification, with limitations on sharing identifiable provider details. Noncompliance sanctions are outlined in the Social Security Act. The Social Security Act outlines sanctions for noncompliance with provider network establishment or modification requirements. Medicare Advantage Plan Compare Tool improvements are mandated within a year of the Act's enactment. Human Services must ensure that the Medicare Advantage Compare Tool considers the preferences and utilization needs of individuals. SEC. 3. NETWORK ADEQUACY. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider factors like anticipated enrollment, services provided, and provider availability when establishing a plan network. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider factors like anticipated enrollment, services provided, and provider availability when establishing a plan network. The organization must also ensure the number and types of providers needed, availability of providers, and timely provision of care as defined by the Secretary. Network access adequacy standards must be applied to ensure timely services. In applying network access adequacy standards, the Secretary seeks input from various stakeholders. Medicare Advantage organizations must certify annually that their plan networks can provide required services and meet enrollees' needs. Each plan year, a Medicare Advantage organization must report to the Secretary on average wait times, utilization of out-of-network providers, and average cost per patient for primary and specialty care under each MA plan offered. The Medicare Advantage organization must certify the accuracy of provider directories for each plan and ensure network adequacy guidelines are met at least once every 3 years. Enforcement is outlined in the Social Security Act. Enforcement for provider directory accuracy and network adequacy guidelines in Medicare Advantage plans is amended in the Social Security Act.
